metadata.case_name: Maharaja Partap Udainath Sah Deo v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Original assessee was Maharaja Partap Udainath Sah Deo, holder of an impartible estate.
On March 20, 1941, assessee granted a prospecting lease of 311 acres to Aluminium Production Company Ltd. for one year; salami at Rs. 100 per acre, royalty at 8 annas per ton.

On January 22, 1944, assessee granted a lease of mining rights over 171-03 acres to same company for 30 years; salami inclusive of Moharkari and Dewani Negi Rs. 5,000 and Rs. 2,25,000; rent 8/- per acre; royalty 6/- per ton; minimum royalty Rs. 22/- per acre.
Area covered by 1944 lease substantially included in 1941 prospecting lease.
For assessment year 1944-45, Income-tax Officer treated Rs. 5,000 as Dewani Negi and Moharkari, balance Rs. 2,20,000 as advance payment of royalty and income of assessee.
On appeal, Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 2,20,000 as salami, capital receipt not taxable.
Appellate Tribunal by order dated August 7, 1952 remanded to Appellate Assistant Commissioner to find if circumstances indicated salami was income.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner report dated April 12, 1956: assessee intentionally accepted lower royalty and higher salami, major portion of Rs. 2,20,000 in exchange of royalty.
Tribunal order dated July 26, 1956 allowed Revenue appeal, restored ITO order.
Patna High Court judgment dated December 22, 1965 in Misc. Judicial Case No. 101 of 1962: Rs. 20,000 as salami (capital), Rs. 2,00,000 revenue receipt taxable.
Reference under s. 66(1) Income-tax Act, 1922 by Tribunal to High Court.
Assessee granted other leases in 1933, 1938, 1945 with royalty 8-12 annas/ton, salami Rs. 100-130/acre.
Mines Superintendent report dated January 7, 1956: area contained commercial grade Bauxite approx. 13 lakh tons.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 2,20,000/- was the income of the assessee assessable to tax under the provisions of the Income-tax Act?

Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 2,20,000 or any portion thereof was the income of the assessee assessable to tax under the provisions of the Income-tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Salami is a capital receipt as single payment for acquisition of lessee's rights; onus on Revenue to show it was advance royalty.
Comparison with 1941 prospecting lease invalid as different purpose (prospecting vs mining), short term (1 year) vs 30 years.
No material to disbelieve lease description; assessee could charge higher salami for long-term lease.

respondent_arguments.text: Salami represented advance royalty as assessee took large salami but lower royalty compared to 1941 lease.
Compared to other leases (1933,1938,1945), salami per acre much higher (Rs.1284 vs Rs.100-130); intentional to avoid tax.
Mines report shows royalty on estimated reserves exceeded salami expectations.

court_reasoning.text: Principles settled: Salami for acquisition of rights is capital; but inquiry if revenue element like advance royalty; onus on tax authorities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: When interest parted for price, it's premium (capital); periodical payments rent (revenue); nomenclature helps but circumstances matter.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal erred relying only on 1941 vs 1944 lease comparison; prospecting different from mining, 1yr vs 30yrs justifies higher salami, lower royalty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of prospecting lease different; legitimate to charge more salami for long possession.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred estimating Rs.20,000 salami based on prior leases without material on minerals there; onus on Revenue not discharged.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No examination of assessee; Mines report post-lease, assessee unaware of reserves.

court_reasoning.text: No camouflage proven as in Panbari Tea; substantial salami alone not capitalised royalty.

holdings.text: Rs. 2,20,000 is salami, capital receipt not taxable as income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Assam etc. v. The Panbari Tea Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No assumption of camouflage without material; salami as described is capital unless proven otherwise.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of question of law by Tribunal to High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; question answered in favour of assessee and against Revenue; Rs. 2,20,000 held capital receipt not taxable.
outcome.relief_granted: Assessee entitled to costs in Supreme Court and High Court.
outcome.costs: Costs to assessee in this Court and High Court.

key_quotes.text: Salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessor by the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to him by the lease. That general right may properly be regarded as a capital asset.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The onus, however, is upon the income tax authorities to show that there exist facts and circumstances which would make payment of what has been called salami, income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Places burden of proof on Revenue.

key_quotes.text: Parties may camouflage the real nature of the transaction by using clever phraseology and, therefore, it is not the form but the circumstances of the transaction that matter.
key_quotes.speaker: court
